text:
“I want to tell
you my secret now.”

M. Night Shyamalan’s “The Sixth Sense”
is the definitive twist ending movie.

But its stroke of genius
is that it actually tells us
the twist halfway through.
“I see dead people.”

Young Cole can communicate
with ghosts, and that includes

the man he’s looking
right at as he says this:
our protagonist Malcolm Crowe.

We saw Malcolm killed
in the opening scene,

even though we, and he, don’t
grasp this until much later
“It doesn't even hurt anymore.”

Shyamalan has said that
the movies with twist endings

that he always comes back to are
“Planet of the Apes” and “Psycho”
films where, in his words,

“…what you thought you
saw you did not see.”

“Are you sure you
saw an old woman?”
“Yes!

In the house
behind the motel!”

This is the guiding principle
of “The Sixth Sense” --

we thought we were watching
a story about a child psychologist

dealing with a crumbling marriage,
but that’s not actually what we saw.

The idea that most of the time we
aren’t seeing what’s in front of us

isn’t just the source of
the film’s magic trick --
it’s also one of its central themes.
“Is something up there?
I don't see anything.”

The way that Shyamalan puts all
the clues right before our eyes,

yet makes us miss
their real meaning,

reinforces how primed
we are to accept
the surface narrative we’re given.

So as “The Sixth Sense”
turns 20 this year,

here’s our take
on how the movie’s

singular surprise ending
proves its central thesis --

that at the movie theater,
and in our own lives,
we see what we want to see.

Before we go on, we want to
talk about this video’s sponsor.

Skillshare is an online
learning community

where you can learn
everything from

video editing to business strategy,
coding or lucid dreaming.

They offer 25,000
online classes

from famous teachers
at the top of their field.

And right now, Skillshare
is offering our viewers

two months access to all
their classes FOR FREE.

So click the link in the description
below, to sign up NOW.

“You haven't told
bedtime stories before.”
“Uh, not too many, no.”

“Well, you have to add
some twists and stuff.”

What’s satisfying about
“The Sixth Sense’s” twist

is it’s foreshadowed
with plenty of signs.

So when it’s revealed
that Malcolm is dead,

this is shocking but,
simultaneously,
makes perfect sense.

The challenge of pulling
off a good twist

is that if an ending
is impossible to anticipate,

it just feels random
and pointless.

How do you plant the seeds
for an earned twist,
without giving away the game?

Here are the clues that,
on second viewing,

tip us off to the fact that Malcolm
has been dead all along:

After Malcolm is shot
in the first scene,

we never see him being saved
or recovering from his wound--
the film simply picks up the next year.

After this point,
the only person

we see Malcolm have
a conversation with is Cole.

We see him around his wife Anna,
but the film cleverly creates reasons

for them not to directly
engage with each other.

When Malcolm gets home,
she’s asleep or in the shower,

and when he meets her at
a restaurant for their anniversary,

we gather she’s coldly ignoring
him as punishment for being late.
“I'm so sorry, Anna.

I just can't
seem to keep track of time.”

When Anna refuses
to look at him, snaps,
“Happy anniversary.”
and leaves as fast as possible

we read this behavior
as reflecting annoyance,
but really, it’s grief.

This widow finds it
too painful to endure

another minute of her
anniversary dinner for one,

because she misses
her husband so much.

Later when we see Malcolm
and Cole’s mother Lynn

waiting for Cole to get home,
we assume they’ve just been talking,

but we never hear a word
exchanged between them.

Lynn doesn’t know
Malcolm is there.
We also get visual clues.
For example,

when Cole tells his
secret to Malcolm,
“How often do you see them?”
“All the time.
They're everywhere.”

the camera focuses on Malcolm,
hinting that what Cole is saying,
“They don’t know they’re dead.”

applies to the man
right in front of him.

Another big thing that helps
make the ending coherent

is strict adherence to the rules
and logic governing the story world.

“So we had to establish rules
about each scene and how

Bruce would interact with people
and situations and physical things.

So for one thing, Malcolm’s clothes
never change in the movie.

“He had to have on the same
clothes the whole time --

but that rule was that it wasn't
necessarily the clothes he

had on when he was shot,
it was clothes that he had
interacted with that evening.”

Malcolm wears the same shirt
and pants, and the sweatshirt

his wife hands him
in the opening scene.
“It’s getting cold.”

Another rule the
filmmakers stuck to

is that most of the time
Malcolm doesn’t have

a physical effect on
his environment.

He repeatedly fails to
open the basement door.

When he goes to the restaurant
to meet Anna, he doesn’t

move the chair at all
when he sits down,

and when he reaches for the check
she conveniently grabs it so

we aren’t tipped off to the fact
that he probably can’t move it.

The exception to this rule
is when he sees Anna

with another man and
breaks a glass door.

The logic is that he can exert
enough force here because

it’s such an emotionally
intense moment.

“With enough effort,
Bruce Willis'character
can impact the physical world.”

Viewers might protest
that a telltale sign of

a nearby ghost is
the temperature dropping.
“It’s cold in here.”

Why then does this not seem
to happen around Malcolm?

Well, one of the filmmakers’
other rules is that this only
happens when a ghost is upset.

“And then we would
see the cold breath

and that was only when the ghost was
angry because people have asked me,

‘Well why don't we see breath when
you see Bruce Willis's character?’
Well it's because he's not angry.”

In the scene where Malcolm
finally connects the dots,

the film does a mini
flashback sequence

to show us that we had
all the information all along.

But Shyamalan is employing
the principles that a magician
uses to pull off his illusion.

"I do my little magic shake,
and now it's in my right hand.”

He’s carefully directing our attention
away from what he’s really doing,

and relying on known
psychological habits

like our instinct
to explain away

what doesn’t make sense,
instead of waiting to resolve

uncertainties until we
have more information.

Another phenomenon
the movie plays on is

that audiences are conditioned
to trust in their main character.

The show Black Mirror
frequently exploits this,

blindsiding viewers by having
the secrets come from within us

i.e., the character
we’re identifying with.

What’s brilliant about this tactic
in “The Sixth Sense” is that

Malcolm is an unknowing
unreliable narrator.

He feels trustworthy
because he believes

the false narrative he
unwittingly feeds us:

that he and Anna
have grown distant,

and that’s why they lead
completely separate lives.

“His wife, doesn't like
the person that he's become.

They barely speak anymore,
they’re like strangers.”

His explanation that Anna
resents his workaholic tendencies

“I haven't paid enough
attention to my family.

Bad things happen
when you do that.”

fits because of what we hear
in the first scene of the movie,
before his death,

“You have put everything
second, including me.”

This early scene
hardly frames this

as a relationship-defining
problem for the couple.

On the contrary, they seem
very happy and in love.

But the movie uses that little sliver
of information to its advantage,

so that we easily believe
Malcolm’s interpretation
of why his marriage is falling apart.

“I know that I've been
a little distant.”
I know that it makes you mad.”

“My goal as a filmmaker is to make --
try to make -- cultural phenomenons.”

“The Sixth Sense” catapulted
its 29 year old director to fame,

earned multiple Oscar-nominations,
and became the second-highest

grossing movie of 1999
at the domestic box office.
The twist was key to this success.

"Hey, if you didn't know
Bruce Willis was dead

the whole time,
that's not on me."

Watching the movie today,
it would be hard not to know

the twist in advance,
thanks to how deeply

ingrained it is in
our cultural memory.

“Oh, did you feel that ice cold
wind that just passed through?”
“I see dead people.”
"I see dead people.”
“Okay.
Spoiler alert.”

“He was dead the whole
time.”
“Just stop it.”

But it’s impossible to
overstate how truly

shocked viewers
were at the time.

The same year, found-footage
horror film “The Blair Witch Project”

went viral through savvy marketing
ploys that convinced some people
it was an actual documentary.

And in a similar way,
“The Sixth Sense”

unlocked the power
of word of mouth.

“That Sunday did more than Friday
which is a really unusual thing --

it means word of mouth is
starting to go (does sound effect).”

1999 was a different time,
and just as Blair Witch’s

marketing campaign relied
on its particular moment

when the world wide web
was far less sophisticated,

“Sixth Sense’s” earth-shattering
twist was a lightning-in-a-bottle
phenomenon that couldn’t be replicated.

Shyamalan never again matched
the critical success of this movie,

which turned him
into -- as he put it --

“the guy who makes
the scary movies with a twist.”

After this, the problem
that plagued Shyamalan

is that when viewers
expect a twist,

it’s almost impossible to
deliver one that satisfies.

Clues have to be increasingly elaborate
to escape the eagle-eyed vigilance

of the viewer who’s
looking for the trick.
“How dumb are you?
You're inside a simulation

of a simulation inside
another giant simulation!”

But the beauty of
“The Sixth Sense”

lay in its simplicity --
how the facts were

all out in the open,
hidden in plain sight.
“That isn't magic."
"What are you talking about?
Of course it's magic.”

The title of “The Sixth Sense”
comes from the expression

for the ability to perceive
something which isn’t

perceivable via the known
physical senses.
“I'm kind of psychic.
I have a fifth sense.”
“What do you mean?”

“It's like I have
ESPN or something.”

In the movie, the “sixth sense”
refers specifically to Cole’s
ability to see ghosts.

The movie connects
this sixth sense to

a physical sensation
we all recognize.

“And the tiny hairs on your arm,
you know when they stand up?”
“Yes.”
“That's them.”

Far from positioning
the ability to see

dead people as
an out-there eccentricity,

the film highlights that all of us
have the potential to sense the dead.

It’s just that most of
us don’t pay attention

or bother to develop
this awareness.

The phrase “sixth sense”
is also used to mean
a strong intuition or gut feeling.

And apart from Cole’s
specific sixth sense,

in a general way this movie underlines
the power of trusting your instincts.

“If you keep your hand
moving long enough,

words and thoughts
start coming out

that you didn't even
know you had in you.

It could be something you
heard somewhere else,

or feelings you had
deep inside of you.”

“A lot of the pieces in
this store communicate,

and I think you should choose
a piece that speaks to you.”

According to this film,
intuition can be our friend,

while the rational mind
can’t always be trusted --

it’s too primed to force all new
information into a pre-approved,
self-serving interpretation of reality.

"Dr. Crowe, you believe
my secret, right?"

"I don't know how to
answer that, Cole.”

For most of the movie,
Malcolm is tortured

by his inability to express to
Anna how much he loves her.

“I want to be able to
talk to my wife again.

The way we used to
talk to each other.”

But after Cole gives
him some advice,
“Wait till she's asleep.
Then she'll listen to you
and she won't even know it.”

Malcolm finally finds
a way to talk to his wife.
“I miss you.”
“I miss you too.”

It’s significant that he’s
only able to reach her
when her conscious mind is down.

The suggestion is that there
are certain important things

that we can only perceive
and absorb on that gut-feeling,
“sixth sense” level.

“My dream is a code
waiting to be broken.”
“You see ghosts, Cole?”
“They want me to do things for them.”

Cole represents a childlike
wisdom and openness,

which the adults we see have
cut themselves off from.
“Some magic’s real.”

If Cole ever does try
to explain the presence

of ghosts to grownups,
they react negatively

“Sometimes people think
they lose things, and they

really didn't lose them--
it just gets moved.”
“You need to leave the table.
Go!”
and find justifications not to listen.

“He's suffering from visual
hallucinations, paranoia.”

The other reason Cole
can see dead people

is because of how
deeply he feels.

Shyamalan has said
that the boy is, quote,

“The perfect person
to see people who

can’t move on with their
lives in the spiritual form

because he sympathizes,
he empathizes so much.”
“You think I'm sad?

What
makes you think that?”
“Your eyes told me.”

The ghosts remain
on earth because
they have unfinished business.

“I just needed to
do a couple things.”

This is the same reason ghosts
hang around in countless stories.
“All ghosts have unfinished business.
That's why they don't cross over.”

What’s different in “The Sixth Sense”,
though, is how the ghosts are limited

in their understanding
of that business.

Cole outlines the ghosts’
three blind spots:
“They don't see each other.

They only see what
they wanna see.
They don't know they're dead.”

Without these three
areas of ignorance,

the ghosts would be able to
complete their agendas a lot faster.

But they’re not ready
to face the truth,

so achieving their business
is intertwined with the ghosts’

process of realizing
they’re deceased.

Even after Malcolm helps Cole solve
the mystery of what the dead want,

“They just want help,
even the scary ones.”

the irony is that Malcolm
doesn’t know he is one

of those very ghosts
in need of help.

Malcolm prides himself
on his work with children,

“You have a gift that teaches
children how to be strong

in situations where most adults
would piss on themselves.”

and the great rupture in his life
is the reappearance of Vincent,

an old client who reveals that
Malcolm’s treatment didn’t work.
“[Screaming] You failed me!”

In fact, Malcolm’s misdiagnosis
may have even exacerbated
Vincent’s condition.

“You told me I was having trouble
coping with my parents' divorce.
You were wrong.”

Malcolm is trying to correct his
mistake with Vincent through Cole,

who reminds him
of his former client

and shares the same
supernatural ability.
“If he can help this new boy,

it will be like… helping
that other one too.”

The second thing weighing on
Malcolm is his need to tell Anna

that he cares more
about her than his work.
“You were never second.
Ever.”

When both missions
are complete,

Malcolm is ready to move
on to some other plane.
“I think I can go now.”

The movie suggests that
ghosts are a huge part of

the fabric of our existence --
they’re all around us, all the time.

“I think maybe when people own
things and then they pass away,

a part of themselves gets printed on
those things, like…like fingerprints.”

The scenes between Malcolm
and Anna visualize this.

In a sense he really is there with
her when she’s speaking to him.
“Good night Malcolm.”
“Goodnight Sweetheart.”

We aren’t as severed from
the dead as we think --

the dead and the living both have
unresolved issues with each other.

Thus once Malcolm fulfills
his purpose on earth,

it’s implied that Anna’s life will
now change for the better, too.

“Everything will be
different in the morning.”

The ghostly presence
can also be interpreted

to symbolize that we’re
constantly haunted by our pasts.

We carry with us so much that’s
happened to us that we can’t let go of.
“He couldn't help that one.
And he can't stop thinking about it.”

You can read “The Sixth Sense”
as a lesson in communication.

“I'm ready to communicate
with you now.”
“Communicate?”

Apparently, Haley Joel Osment’s
father told the child actor

to look at the script this way:
as a story about communication.
It’s all the ghosts really want.

“She wanted to
tell you something.”

While for the living, it’s just
as hard and just as essential.

“If we can't talk to each other,
we're not gonna make it.”

The true success of
Malcolm and Cole’s

relationship is that it enables both
of them to connect with other people.

“I think we said everything
we needed to say.
Maybe

it's time to say things
to someone closer to you.”

Cole finally opens up to his mom
by explaining how his ability

has allowed him to speak
to her mother’s ghost.

“You thought she didn't come
to see you dance.
She did.”

In this moment Cole resolves his
grandmother’s unfinished business --

making sure her daughter
knows that she is loved.

“She said the answer is…
every day.
What did you ask?”
“Do I make her proud?”

But this scene results in
Cole and his mother bonding,

reinforcing that this young boy’s
journey is not just about passing

on messages for others
but of him learning to

communicate in a way
that’s healing and beneficial.

It seems that Cole must know
Malcolm is dead from the beginning.

“You're nice, but
you can't help me.”

We see Malcolm
through his own eyes,

as he wants to appear,
not as a dead person.

But Cole sees all
the other ghosts

sporting the physical
consequences of their deaths.

So we can imagine Malcolm appears
to him with a visible bullet wound.

Cole seems a little
frightened of Malcolm at first,
“Wanna sit?”

and he never has any
confusion as to whether

anyone else he meets
is alive or dead.

The fact that Cole doesn’t
tell Malcolm he’s dead

doesn’t really prove anything,
either, as we don’t see him

tell any other ghosts
that they’re dead.

Most likely he knows that
ghosts don’t react well

to this information, or that they
need to realize it on their own.

“The Sixth Sense” has many parallels
to “The Exorcist”, which Shyamalan

has cited as one of
his favorite movies.

Both tell the story
of an innocent child

who experiences strange
supernatural phenomena.
“What happened to my child today?

Something was happening to
him, physically happening.
Something was very wrong!”
“Did you see her or not?

She's acting like she's
[Bleep] out of her mind!”
The child has a single mother,

“I don't know
if you noticed,

but our little family
isn't doing so good.”
“Where's her father?”
“In Europe.”

and there’s a suggestion
that all this horror may

stem from the psychological toll
of the father abandoning the family.

“Did you ever write any upset
words before your father left?”
“I don’t remember.”

“You mentioned her father
and the separation…”

In “The Exorcist”,
the priest becomes

substitute father
figures for Reagan.

Here, the childless Malcolm
steps into that role for lonely Cole.
“He said the play sucked big time.”
“This Tommy kid sounds like a real punk.
I thought the play was excellent.”

The key difference between
the two movies, though,

lies in the nature of the otherworldly
forces and their intentions.

In “The Exorcist,”
Reagan is afflicted

by a horrible demon that
needs to be destroyed.

In “The Sixth Sense,”
the ghosts turn out

to be manageable and
even benevolent.

So there’s an optimistic
view of whatever

supernatural forces
may be out there.

And the story has an uplifting
message, in that this kid --

who begins as a social outcast
suffering under the weight of his

special ability, is eventually
empowered by his contact

with these spirits, learning to
use his skill as a force for good.
“You liked it, she said.”

Throughout “The Sixth Sense,”
the color red connotes

the presence of
the otherworldly.

“We used the color red to indicate
anything in the real world that
has been tainted by the other world.”

So we see a red balloon and
red carpeting on the stairs

leading to the “dungeon”
where Cole -- dressed

in a red sweater -- is
abused by a ghost,

the red fort where Cole
hides from ghosts,

and the red Kyra’s mother, and
killer, wears at Kyra’s memorial.

At the end of the movie when Cole
plays King Arthur in the school play,

he victoriously lifts Excalibur
which bears a red stone --

so we understand that what
was once a curse is now a gift.

Just as King Arthur
was one in a million --

the only person capable of
pulling the sword from the stone --

Cole is a chosen one
with an important destiny.
“It’s for you.”

The ghosts’ inability
to look past what they

want to see encapsulates
the movie’s central theme:

our collective failure to grasp
what’s really in front of us.

At the end, we get a wider shot
revealing that all this time

the basement door Malcolm keeps
failing to open has been barricaded.

He never noticed because
he’s been tuning out anything

that could have tipped him
off to the fact that he’s dead.

And the movie features other examples
of our common instinct to explain away

what doesn’t fit
our preconceptions,

like when Lynn is startled
to find her cupboards open,
but quickly thinks of an explanation.

“Something you were
looking for, baby?”
Cole’s central speech,
“They only see what they want to see.”

is really also about the living --
about us, the audience.

And the deeper
message in his words

is that when we ignore
what’s in front of us,

blinded by the rigid narrative in
our heads, we aren’t really living.

We’re just drifting
around like ghosts,

listlessly failing to impact or
interact with the world around us.

Early in the movie, Cole tells Malcolm
that he got in trouble for drawing

a grisly scene clearly based on
one of the dead people he sees.
“I drew a man.

He got hurt in the neck
by another man with a screwdriver.”

Cole has internalized that the people
around him don’t want him to be honest.
“I don't draw like that anymore.”
“How do you draw now?”

“I draw... people smiling,
dogs running, rainbows.”

From the time that we’re children,
we’re trained to willfully ignore

difficult truths, until we find them
harder and harder to see at all.

Cole’s journey to let go of his
learned defenses against the truth

is also Malcolm’s journey,
as he gradually lets down

the subconscious walls
of denial he’s built.

And like Cole and Malcolm,
we have to learn to look
what scares us in the face.

Because while seeing
what we want to see

may be easier
in the short-term,

only the honest picture
can bring us lasting peace.
“I don't want to be scared anymore.”
